title: Was told to pay restitution can I file Bankruptcy on the amount?
question: I can only find a job to pay me eight bucks an hour even though I have a college education due to the felony on my record. I was ordered to pay restitution but can not due to lack of funds. Can I include this and probation costs that are way to high as well. By the way I have 8 kids and a sick husband who does work but misses a lot due to his aggressive disease and was given only another year or so before he begins to lose his limbs. Thanks for your help
answers:
You really have two questions. First is can you include the debt. That answer is yes. You must list every debt that you have. The second is can it be discharged. The answer there is no. Talk to a consumer law attorney about what you can do so that you can afford this debt. Talk to the creditor and see if you can work out a reasonable payment.

Talk to a criminal law attorney about whether California allows for expungements after a period of time (Virginia would not) or whether you can do anything about your criminal record.

[I am a Virginia-licensed attorney. This communication is intended as general information and not specific legal advice, and this communication does not create an attorney-client relationship.]

I hope this helps. If you think this post was helpful, please check the thumbs up (helpful) tab below. Thank you!

The criminal restitution ordered would not be dischargeable in bankruptcy.

No. Court ordered restitution and probation fees are not dischargeable in bankruptcy. The law is what it is and looks at what is and is not discharged, not the reasons that a hardship exists. Sorry. However, bankruptcy may discharge enough of your other obligations so that you can pay for your non dischargeable debt.
